g.text: • both act as the same authority
• runs as a service with its own URI
• client generates its own public and private key pair to sign assertions and authenticate to RPs
• public keys are published at the clients well-known URI
• uses a JWT client authentication to authenticate to RPs
• acts as a Relying Party in respect of the IdP in order to obtain an access_token_with_user_claims
• acts as a token forwarder that forwards tokens from the STS to the RP
• is a resource server using the local ABAC engine to automate authorization assessment
1. Client generates the resource_claims_token with these claims:
iss is the URI that identifies who issues the resource_claims_token
aud is the URI that identifies the requested resource
exp, nbf are the standard JWT claims
and generate the authentication JWT with these claims:
aud is the URI that identifies the IdP
jti, exp are the standard JWT claims
4. STS generates the identity_claims_token with these claims:
iss is the URI that identifies who issues the identity_claims_token
aud identifies the target service and it is the aud claim value extracted from the resource_claims_token
sub identifies the principal by email address and was extracted from the access_token_with_user_claims
exp, nbf are the standard JWT claims
act{sub} is the sub value extracted from the resource_claims_token
5. Return the identity_claims_token in the access_token parameter,
6. Send HTTP request to resource_uri with the identity_claims_token,
and generate the authentication JWT with these claims:
aud is the URI that identifies the requested resource
jti, exp are the standard JWT claims
8. Return HTTP response, typically with 200, 201 status code
